prefix: Approach the following question the way someone in elementary school would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone in elementary school would. You are given that $3^{400}\equiv 1\pmod{1000}$. What are the last three digits of $3^{12000}$?
solution:
The last three digits are the same as the remainder when divided by $1000$.

$3^{400}\equiv 1\pmod{1000}\implies 3^{12000}=(3^{400})^{30}\equiv 1^{30}=1\pmod{1000}$.

Thus, the last three digits are $\boxed{001}$.
gpt_response:
Oh cool! So we know that $3^{400}\equiv 1\pmod{1000}$. This means that $3^{400}$ leaves a remainder of 1 when divided by 1000. 

Now, we want to find the last three digits of $3^{12000}$. We can write $3^{12000}$ as $3^{400} \cdot 3^{400} \cdot 3^{400} \cdot \ldots \cdot 3^{400}$ (30 times in total) because $12000$ is divisible by $400$. 

Since $3^{400}\equiv 1\pmod{1000}$, each grouping of $3^{400}$ will leave a remainder of 1 when divided by 1000. So, $3^{12000}$ will also leave a remainder of 1 when divided by 1000.

Therefore, the last three digits of $3^{12000}$ are $\boxed{001}$.
